description: Back-formation from sulky, of uncertain origin. Probably from Middle English *sulke, *solke (attested in solcennesse (‚Äúidleness; laziness‚Äù), from Old English ƒÅsolcennys (‚Äúidleness; slothfulness; sluggishness; laziness‚Äù), from ƒÅsolcen (‚Äúsulky, languid‚Äù), from past participle of Old English ƒÅseolcan (‚Äúbe slow; be weak or slothful; languish‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *selkanƒÖ (‚Äúto fall in drops; dribble; droop‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *s√©l«µ-o-nom, from *sel«µ- (‚Äúto let go, send‚Äù). Cognate with several Indo-Iranian words deriving from Proto-Indo-Iranian *sar»∑ÃÅ- (such as Sanskrit ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡§ø (s·πõj√°ti), ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡§ø (sarjati), ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§® (s√°rjana), ‡§∏‡•É‡§ï (s·πõk√°)), possibly Hittite íä≠íÄ†íÄùíç£ (≈°a-al-ak-zi /≈°alkzi/, ‚Äúknead, mix‚Äù), although the semantic connection is weak.

examples: Leo has been in a sulk all morning.
Don't be such a sulk, Leo!

verbs.description: sulk (third-person singular simple present sulks, present participle sulking, simple past and past participle sulked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To express ill humor or offence by remaining sullenly silent or withdrawn.
